Product Process,
Project Pricing

The return on investment exceeds the cost of the project

The most successful way to achieve a superior product is to go through the correct process. For product design, this is a process of creating requirements, documenting purpose, and refining ideas. Requirements understanding is broken up into phases for delivery. Each phase drills down into product requirements in more detail.

The idea around having phased engagements is to define requirements and understand what needs to be built for the product. Products should never be built based on gut-feelings or assumptions of user and user needs. After each phase, you will have a document package that you can take with you and use it to shop around for additional refinement or development. We would of course like to tackle your project from start to finish; Discovery, Refinement, Development, and Product Review.

The product process helps:

  • Clearly articulate high-level requirements
  • Refine requirements, documentation, and concepts
  • Speed up development through understanding
  • Validate a product through testing with real users, analyzing results, and applying user feedback
  • Weed out potential issues sooner, saving time fixing or concepting design, flow, and interaction problems later

Our budget-conscious clients trend towards shorter engagements. We understand, however we do want to communicate that with less time in the refinement phase we will have less time to more finely define requirements, find and close gaps, and create and refine aesthetic, and document concepts. This may leave you with more uncertainty as you move on to the development phase.

We only bill for the hours we actually work – that means that if we propose something will take four weeks and it takes two weeks, we only bill for two weeks worth of work.

We offer a ten percent discounted rate for clients who sign a contract for more than one phase upfront. However, because the purpose of understanding requirements helps us estimate later phases of work, we will have to come to an agreement at the time of signing the contract for contingencies for adding more time once we have more certainty around requirements.

Discovery Phase

Four to Eight weeks – $26,400 to $52,800
Purpose
  • Define the product from the point of view of the stakeholder
  • Define the user through survey and observation
  • Understand the user’s needs for the product
  • Align and refine stakeholder wants and user needs
  • Define user tasks for the Product
  • Define clear, high-level requirements
Deliverables
  • Documentation of high-level project requirements
  • Documentation of understanding and base-level conceptualization of the project
  • Personas based on user research
  • Perfect-path task lists for how users will approach a product
  • User-focused journey maps based on product understanding and tasks
  • High-level project roadmap for project concepts and features starting with MVP
  • Estimation for product refinement phase
Details

The best way to a successful project is to start with a clear vision of what needs to be built. The purpose of a product discovery phase is to understand and clearly articulate high-level requirements for a product. The goals of the client are examined and itemized, and both the client and the end user help to influence the high-level requirements throughout the discovery phase.

The more information that is known prior to a discovery phase will help to speed up the process. However any prior understanding and assumptions will be questioned by the product designer to create a clear understanding of requirements.

A typical discovery phase can be completed in six to ten weeks, depending on the size and scope of the product. Smaller products will typically take less time to research and develop high-level requirements. Larger products will take longer. The more time we have to spend with a project of any size, the more confidence we have in our high-level recommendations.

Product Refinement Phase

Six to Eighteen weeks – $39,600 to $118,800
Purpose
  • Create user flows based on product understanding
  • Vet and refine user flows through stakeholder and developer meetings
  • Develop wireframes for how the layout of the product should work based on user flows
  • Design a user test around understanding of the user, the tasks they will perform, and the product user flows
  • Create testable prototypes based on wireframes (prototype functionality dependent on the project and product)
  • Test the prototypes with real users (three to five users per test) with frequency
  • Refine tasks, layouts, and flows as we better understand how the user will interact with the product
  • Repeat: Develop, Design, Create, Test, Refine
Deliverables
  • Versioned user flows
  • Versioned task lists
  • Identification for edge-case tasks
  • Versioned wireframes and mockups
  • Versioned prototypes
  • A Zeplin style guide and component documentation for handoff to developers
  • Documentation of user testing, feedback, and highlights
  • Documentation of finely-defined project requirements (stories and issues for backlog)
  • Documentation of goals and understanding of the project
  • Estimation for the development phase
Details

In the product refinement phase, our goal is to drill-down into the understanding gained in the discovery phase to finely define project requirements within the allotted time frame. The more time we have to refine goals and requirements, the more certainty we will have in our recommendations. That said, the less time we have to explore and define project requirements, the less certainty we will have around our recommendations.

The product refinement phase picks up from where the discovery phase leaves off. We take the defined high-requirements from the discovery phase and refine them through ideation, testing, and iteration.

Visual Design

Decisions about the visual aesthetic of the user interface UI start to come into play after initial rounds of refinement have taken place. Having existing brand requirements helps to speed the visual process along, however, adding visual value is incremental and needs to be tested. With each repetition of Develop, Design, Create, Test, and Refine, we will iterate on the visual aesthetic of the mockups. UI design moves from:

  1. Wireframes – rough layout concepts to communication content and placement – to
  2. Low-fidelity mockups – cleaned up versions of the rough layout concepts – to
  3. Medium-fidelity mockups – transitional design beginning to add branding concepts – to
  4. High-fidelity mockups – tested and vetted visuals that will serve as the visual requirements for the layout, placement, and development of the product

The goal of iterative product design is to create and prove why components, content, and interactions are placed where they are. We strongly recommend not jumping forward with the aesthetic design until the product concept has been fully tested. There are several reasons for not going high-fidelity visual design too quickly:

  1. It takes time to make a product look really good aesthetically. Testing and iterating through a product can cause layouts and flows to be torn down, thrown out, and rethought, thus wasting the time spent creating the high-fidelity design.
  2. Similarly, it takes time to iterate on any fidelity mockup, but the more pixel perfect the design gets, the longer it takes to make changes.
  3. In testing, users are less likely to give direct and honest feedback if an application looks “finished”. When the design is a little more rough, a user is more likely to suggest larger changes to a product or a layout.
  4. We simply don’t know what our high-fidelity recommendations for your product will be without iterating through the process. If you are looking for concept design to help you get funding for your project, we do offer that as a service, but the process is different than in the refinement phase, and we strongly advise for any concept designs to then be tested and vetted with users before they are used to make product requirements.

For longer engagements, we will bring on a visual designer to work alongside the product designer. We will bring them up to speed on the product, and they will support moving from low- to high-fidelity UI design.

The more time we have to Develop, Design, Create, Test, and Refine and move through visual design, we:

  • Identify and fill gaps
  • Vet concepts with our developers so we are proposing concepts that we know can be built and built efficiently
  • Explore and document all possible states of UI components
  • Develop a more complete style guide
  Short Medium Large
Requirements Clear Clearer Clearest
Certainty Medium High Highest
User touchpoints Some (8 to 16+) Many (16 to 24+) Plenty (24 to 32+)
Definition of states States for MVP States for future versions All* States in UI concept
Prototype Click-through Some data simulation Task-based data simulation
Backlog Loosely defined Somewhat defined Ready for development
Aesthetic design Low-fidelity Medium-fidelity High-fidelity
Styleguide Zeplin – Defined and documented for MVP Zeplin – Defined and documented for future versions (based on understanding of states of components) Zeplin – Fully defined for known states
HTML/CSS style guide - atomic and for base elements

Product Support Contract

~Eight to Sixteen weeks – $6,600/week
Purpose
  • Contracted time to work alongside of a developer to respond to any questions or gaps
  • Contracted time to review the product in development and help keep on track with the proposed vision of the product
Deliverables
  • Any additional documentation created, updated to the project documentation
  • Any additional state documentation created, updated to the project documentation
  • Any additional aesthetic design created, updated to the style guide
Details

From our experience, even from the most complete refinement phases and complete style guides, and complete documentation, there will always be a certain level of uncertainty and product functionality and the user interface when it comes to development. This is why we offer product support contracts that range from part-time to full-time engagement.

A full-time product support contract will especially be important for those clients who have chosen a shorter refinement phase. This allows a product designer the time necessary to define and outline any edge cases that may arise in development, or to flesh out any interactions and components that were not given enough time or attention in earlier phases.

One of the most common occurrences we see speaking to the value of a support contract is a developer asking “what is the __component name__ supposed to look like in a resting/active/disabled/fill-in-the-blank state?”. A support contract gives you the piece of mind that everything will have eyes on it and decisions will be based on understanding and documentation – as opposed to someone else making the decision that it should “probably be like this” or worse “that is good enough”.

We recommend budgeting for a full-time, forty hour a week, product designer for every week of your development contract if you chose a shorter refinement phase, or we did not perform your refinement phase, and there is more uncertainty around your product.

We recommend budgeting for a part-time, ten or twenty hour per week, product designer for every week of your development contract if we performed your product refinement phase, but did a shorter engagement due to budget constraints.

Product Review Contract

One to Two weeks – $6,600 to $13,200
Purpose

After development is done, near to when your product is ready to launch, we want to re-engage with users and test to see if all requirements are met, if the application works as expected.

Deliverables
  • User testing reports highlighting successes and shortfalls
  • Recommendations for improvements
  • Estimation for next phase of engagement (Let’s build those next features together!)
